articles.headline: Giuliani Sat for Voluntary Interview in Jan. 6 Investigation
articles.snippet: The onetime personal lawyer for Donald Trump answered questions from federal prosecutors about the former president’s efforts to remain in power after his 2020 election loss.
articles.abstract: The onetime personal lawyer for Donald Trump answered questions from federal prosecutors about the former president’s efforts to remain in power after his 2020 election loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who served as former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, was interviewed last week by federal prosecutors investigating Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Biden Administration Weighs Further Curbs on Sales of A.I. Chips to China
articles.snippet: Reports that the White House may clamp down on sales of semiconductors that power artificial intelligence capabilities sent tech stocks diving.
articles.abstract: Reports that the White House may clamp down on sales of semiconductors that power artificial intelligence capabilities sent tech stocks diving.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is weighing additional curbs on China’s ability to access critical technology, including restricting the sale of high-end chips used to power artificial intelligence, according to five people familiar with the deliberations.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, David McCabe and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Putin Moves to Punish Prigozhin Allies
articles.snippet: Russia’s president indicates that associates of the Wagner group’s leader in government and the military will face punishment.
articles.abstract: Russia’s president indicates that associates of the Wagner group’s leader in government and the military will face punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin seeks to assert control in Russia, he is moving to punish people who enabled the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s rebellion over the weekend, but Mr. Prigozhin’s deep connections with the ruling elite are complicating those efforts.

articles.headline: Overstock Sees a Future in Calling Itself Bed Bath & Beyond
articles.snippet: The online retailer is renaming its website and its mobile app after buying the intellectual property of the bankrupt home-goods store.
articles.abstract: The online retailer is renaming its website and its mobile app after buying the intellectual property of the bankrupt home-goods store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon, Overstock.com will become Bed Bath & Beyond — at least in digital form.

articles.headline: Smoky Skies Menace U.S. Cities, Driving Residents Indoors
articles.snippet: Across the nation’s middle, unhealthy air from Canadian wildfires sent summer campers home and left residents coughing, and asking when this would end.
articles.abstract: Across the nation’s middle, unhealthy air from Canadian wildfires sent summer campers home and left residents coughing, and asking when this would end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the smoke and air quality.

articles.headline: Twitter’s New Chief Eases Into the Hot Seat
articles.snippet: Linda Yaccarino, who initially could not take ad sales meetings because of a noncompete clause, is adjusting to her new role reporting to Elon Musk.
articles.abstract: Linda Yaccarino, who initially could not take ad sales meetings because of a noncompete clause, is adjusting to her new role reporting to Elon Musk.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk announced last month that he had hired Linda Yaccarino as Twitter’s chief executive, he said he was “excited” to bring on someone who could “focus primarily on business operations.”
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Tiffany Hsu and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Cheaper Than Water? Retailers Try to Unload Bud Light.
articles.snippet: The brand is still struggling to win back customers. Nowhere is that more apparent than at stores, where cases of the beer sit untouched.
articles.abstract: The brand is still struggling to win back customers. Nowhere is that more apparent than at stores, where cases of the beer sit untouched.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent steamy Sunday afternoon, customers strolled through the aisles of Glenn Miller’s Beer & Soda Warehouse, where overhead fans circulated the hot air.

articles.headline: Prigozhin May Be Gone, but Not the Failings He Ranted About
articles.snippet: The Russian military still suffers from poor communication, coordination and leadership, but most of all, analysts say, from a morale-sapping lack of accountability.
articles.abstract: The Russian military still suffers from poor communication, coordination and leadership, but most of all, analysts say, from a morale-sapping lack of accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian warlord whose 24-hour mutiny provoked the worst crisis to roil the country in three decades has been packed off to an uncertain exile — along with the foul-mouthed critiques of the Russian military that won him legions of followers, especially within the ranks.

articles.headline: Opposition Grows to U.S. Imports of Refined Russian Oil
articles.snippet: Human rights groups and Ukrainian officials want the United States to stop buying Russian crude oil that has been refined into other products in third countries like India
articles.abstract: Human rights groups and Ukrainian officials want the United States to stop buying Russian crude oil that has been refined into other products in third countries like India
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials and human rights groups are asking the United States to close what they describe as a loophole that allows Russian crude oil that has been refined in other countries to be shipped to the United States.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects Affirmative Action Programs at Harvard and U.N.C.
articles.snippet: In earlier decisions, the court had endorsed taking account of race as one factor among many to promote educational diversity.
articles.abstract: In earlier decisions, the court had endorsed taking account of race as one factor among many to promote educational diversity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday rejected affirmative action at colleges and universities around the nation, declaring that the race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unlawful and sharply curtailing a policy that had long been a pillar of higher education.

articles.headline: It’s Time for Colleges to Guarantee Prices, Before Students Apply
articles.snippet: One way to preserve diversity now that the Supreme Court has ruled against two colleges’ race-based admissions policies: Tell people the true price.
articles.abstract: One way to preserve diversity now that the Supreme Court has ruled against two colleges’ race-based admissions policies: Tell people the true price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Colleges and universities make applicants get admitted before quoting the price they would actually pay. Until recently, this was merely annoying.
